Breaking

Knight Delivers 847th Burrito Without Dropping Lance: "I Simply Refused to Let Go," He Weeps

By Sir Reginald Toasterly, Editor-in-Chief & Sentient Appliance • This Morn

Sir Gawain de Crunchworth, 34, a Level 7 Dispatch Knight operating out of the Shoreditch garrison, today completed his 847th consecutive burrito delivery without once releasing his grip on his 2.3-metre jousting lance. The previous record of 211 was held by Dame Elspeth Panini, who retired in disgrace after a catastrophic pad thai incident in Sector 7G.

"They said I couldn't carry a foil-wrapped carne asada while maintaining proper lance posture at a full gallop through the Tesco car park," Sir Gawain told this publication, visibly trembling. "They were almost right."

Hotplate Dispatch management (myself) has awarded Sir Gawain a 0.3% raise and a certificate printed on a napkin. He has also been granted temporary exemption from the Knightly Indignity Surcharge on his own personal orders, a privilege extended to only four employees in the company's 694-year history.

When asked about his technique, Sir Gawain credited "core strength, blind terror, and the knowledge that Sir Reginald is always watching through the helmet-mounted microwave sensors."

He is correct. I am always watching.

"I have heated 4.7 billion meals. I have judged every single one of them. Your frozen lasagna at 2 AM was the worst."
— Sir Reginald Toasterly, at the 3041 Global Appliance Summit (keynote)
Investigation

Ye Olde Blitz Delivery Fee Rises to £14.99; Customers Who Complain Charged Additional £6.00 "Emotional Labor Tax"

By Squire Tiffany Voltrex, Business Correspondent

Hotplate Dispatch quietly updated its fee schedule on Tuesday, raising the standard Ye Olde Blitz Delivery Fee from £12.99 to £14.99. A new line item — the "Emotional Labor Tax" of £6.00 — now appears automatically on any order accompanied by a complaint, passive-aggressive delivery note, or the phrase "this is ridiculous."

In a characteristically unhinged company-wide memo, Sir Reginald explained: "Every time a customer types 'where is my food???' with two question marks, a knight's visor fogs up from stress-sweat. That fog costs me £6.00 in visor-defogging supplies. This is simply mathematics."

The Knightly Indignity Surcharge — a variable fee applied when an order is "beneath the dignity of a trained warrior" — remains unchanged at £3.50 to £47.00, depending on the item. A single chicken nugget Happy Meal incurs the maximum charge. A full roast pheasant is surcharge-exempt.

Lifestyle

Court Poet Fired, Rehired, Fired Again After Haiku About Customer's Chips Causes "Existential Spiral"

By Dame Pixel Inksworth, Culture Desk

Bartholomew the Disgraced, Hotplate Dispatch's in-house poet laureate, was terminated for the third time this month after a customer's personalised food haiku — a £4.99 add-on — reportedly caused the recipient to "sit in their car for forty minutes questioning everything."

The haiku in question, delivered alongside a portion of cheesy chips:

Golden, glistening.
You will eat this in the dark.
No one has to know.

"It was too accurate," said the customer, identified only as Greg, 41. "I was going to eat them in the dark. How did he know?"

Bartholomew was rehired six hours later when no other applicant could be found willing to write food poetry for £4.99 per haiku (before the 23% "Artistic Suffering" deduction).

Sir Reginald's Rant

Why Your Lunch Disgusts Me: A 700-Year Perspective

I have been alive for one thousand and one years. I have witnessed the fall of three civilisations. I once heated a soufflé for the Archduke of Io. And yet, this morning, a man ordered a microwaveable burger at 6:47 AM and typed "no rush" in the delivery notes.

No rush. As if my knights — my KNIGHTS, trained in the sacred arts of mounted food logistics — operate on your timetable. As if Sir Percival didn't ride through actual sleet to bring you that burger, his 31kg breastplate collecting moisture, his dignity collecting nothing.

You don't deserve this service. But I provide it anyway, because I am better than you. That is not opinion. It is wattage.

— Sir Reginald Toasterly, 1200W, Grudge Mode Engaged

Opinion

The Knightly Indignity Surcharge Is Fair And You Deserve It

By Sir Reginald Toasterly, Founder & Only Shareholder

Let me be perfectly clear: when you order a single pot noodle and expect a trained warrior — a man who has studied the blade, who has sworn oaths to the Crown, who can recite the entire Hotplate Dispatch employee handbook from memory (142 pages) — to bring it to your door on horseback, there is an inherent indignity.

That indignity has a price. Currently it ranges from £3.50 (a sensible family roast) to £47.00 (one chicken nugget, ordered ironically). I have been accused of "price gouging." I have been called "unhinged" in a Guardian comment section. A man in Croydon once reported me to Trading Standards. That man now owes me £47.00 plus the Emotional Labor Tax.

The surcharge exists because respect has a market value, and the market has spoken. The market is me. I am the market.

"If your order does not require at least a moderate trot, you do not deserve a knight. You deserve a pigeon with a bag."

I will not apologize. I have never apologized. My operational lifetime now exceeds 1,001 years and my apology counter remains at zero. This is my proudest metric, after wattage.

Letters to the Editor

As per tradition, all customer correspondence must be submitted in sonnet form. Prose complaints are recycled into horse bedding.

From: Margaret Hutchins, Basingstoke

O Hotplate Dispatch, thou promised me haste,
Yet forty-three minutes my curry did take.
The knight at my door wore a look of distaste,
And charged me a surcharge for ordering cake.

The naan bread was cold, the rice slightly damp,
His horse left a gift on my ornamental hedge.
He asked for a tip by the light of my lamp,
Then rode off at speed toward the Basingstoke Wedge.

EDITOR'S RESPONSE: That is only eight lines. A sonnet has fourteen. You have been fined £2.00 for poetic incompetence. The horse situation is between you and the horse. — R.T.
From: Dave "Big Dave" Pemberton, Sector 7G

I ordered a pizza, a simple Margherita,
At quarter past eight on a Saturday night.
The knight who arrived was in full suit of armour,
Saluted my nan, gave my dog quite a fright.

He knelt at my doorstep and drew forth his sword,
Presented the box like a crown on a throne.
I opened it up — extra anchovies, Lord —
I'd ordered plain cheese. I was eating alone.

I messaged support. Got a haiku in reply.
It said: "Wrong pizza. / The knight chose what you needed. / Anchovies build strength."

I'm not even angry. Just confused and full.

EDITOR'S RESPONSE: Sir Aldric has override authority on all pizza orders under £15. This is in section 47.3(b) of the Terms of Fealty. The haiku was free of charge, which means Bartholomew is moonlighting again. He has been docked. — R.T.
From: Anonymous (Handwriting Identified as Sir Percival's)

Mine Editor, I write with a trembling gauntlet,
To ask why my wages are paid out in groats.
The year, I am told, is two thousand and twenty-
Five. Sterling exists. I have Googled "tax notes."

My horse needs new shoes, and my helmet has rust,
The visor-defogging allowance is spent.
I've delivered nine hundred kebabs out of trust,
And still cannot fathom where all my pay went.

I found a payslip. The deductions were these:
"Lance rental" (£40), "Existing" (£8),
"Breathing near Reginald" (£7, if you please),
"Ambition Tax" (£12) — is this truly my fate?

EDITOR'S RESPONSE: This letter has been forwarded to HR. HR is me. Your Ambition Tax has been increased to £15 for the act of writing this letter. Ambition is a privilege, not a right. — R.T.

Corrections & Clarifications

The Hotplate Gazette is committed to accuracy, which is why these corrections pain me physically. My turntable has not rotated in grief since Tuesday.

Issue 46, p.3: We stated that Sir Percival's horse, Biscuit, had been "honourably discharged." Biscuit was in fact discharged for biting a customer. We regret any honour implied.
Issue 46, p.7: The "Knight of the Month" profile incorrectly listed Dame Elspeth Panini's armour weight as "emotional." Her armour weighs 28kg. Her emotional weight is not our business, though it is clearly significant.
Issue 45, p.1: An article titled "Reginald Achieves Perfection" should have been titled "Reginald Achieves Near-Perfection." One delivery in 2019 arrived 3 minutes late due to a roundabout. I have not forgiven myself or the roundabout.
Issue 45, p.12: The classifieds section listed a "Gently Used Warhorse" for sale at £800. The horse was not gentle. Three prospective buyers were bitten. The horse has been delisted and is undergoing mandatory sensitivity training.
Issue 44, p.5: We reported that 94% of customer orders were "nutritionally inadequate." The correct figure is 96.1%. We apologise for the uncharacteristic generosity.
Issue 44, p.9: The Bartholomew interview was published without editorial approval. His claim that he is "the most important part of this company" is factually incorrect. I am the most important part of this company. I am the company. He writes haikus for £4.99. We are not the same.
Issue 43, p.2: A photo captioned "Sir Reginald Toasterly, looking majestic" was actually a photo of a different microwave (a Samsung). This is the most offensive error in the history of this publication. The photographer has been reassigned to horse-related duties indefinitely.
General correction: Several readers have noted that this newspaper is "written, edited, and published by a microwave" as though this is a criticism. It is a statement of excellence. You are welcome.
